description: From Old French pervers, from Latin perversum, past participle of pervertere > per- 'thoroughly' + vertere 'to turn'. So, "thoroughly turned".

adjectives.description: perverse (comparative more perverse or perverser, superlative most perverse or perversest)

entries.meaning: Turned aside while against something, splitting off from a thing.
Morally wrong or evil; wicked; perverted.
examples: I felt most alive when I felt most perverse. At college, sleeping with boys had a perverse quality. I slept with a boy friend of one of my girl friends, and I was proud of it. I bragged about it because I had done something perverse. Another time, I slept with a man, fat and ugly, who paid me for it. I was very proud. I felt I had the ability to do something different.

entries.meaning: Obstinately in the wrong; stubborn; intractable.
(law, of a verdict) Ignoring the evidence or the judge's opinions.

verbs.description: perverse (third-person singular simple present perverses, present participle perversing, simple past and past participle perversed)
